p.s: In the second scene of Act II of William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet, Romeo sneaks into the Capulet's garden to speak to Juliet.
As he comes out of hiding, Juliet is quite concerned at first.
She tells Romeo how he'll be dead, killed by her family if they happen to see him at their house.
Romeo on the other hand does not care about being in danger and says that Juliet's kinsmen would not be able to stop him or his love.
As Juliet still goes on about Romeo being in danger, he tells her that he'd rather be dead than her not loving her.
By the thought of Romeo hearing her monologue Juliet blushes.
To reassure that Romeo really loves her she asks him to declare it faithfully, but warns him that if he swears and breaks his promise in the end they will be laughed about.

As she also is concerned that Romeo may think she is easy to get and irresponsible, she reassures him of her truthfullnesstruthfulness by referring back to her love confessing Monologuemonologue whom she did not think Romeo was hearing.

Wanting to prove his love Romeo starts to swear by the moon but is interrupted by Juliet who tells him not to by the inconsistent moon but to either not swear at all or to swear by himself and she would believe him.
